frameDefinitions: An Entity is obscure, unnotable, and in general little-known.
An Agent resolves an outstanding Problem by finding its solution, explanation, answer, etc.
An Entity is presented as having been seen or experienced by a (typically generic and backgrounded)
An Evaluee, which can be a person or an object, has an amount of acceptability or utilization based on general (often non-aesthetic) desirability.

A Behavior, attributed to an Evaluee, conforms with or is heavily influenced by a popular trend or practice, often in the realm of fashion, design, though extending social and interactional behavior in general.
The adjectives and nouns in this frame are all based on the idea that mental properties may be attributed to a person (Protagonist) by a (usually implicit)
frameExamples: Geoffrey Rush was <t>little</t> <t>known</t> outside his native Australia when he soared to international prominence.
As it turns out, putting all of my eggs in one basket completely <t>solved</t> all of my problems.
Susanna Fulton's work is <t>new</t> to me.
Wearing flowered brocaded silks was <t>fashionable</t> in the first few years of the decade.
It was <t>stupid</t> of me to do that.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Entity</fen> which is not widely known and rather obscure.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Entity</fen> is not well known.
The location where the <fen>Entity</fen> is not famous.
The <fen>Agent</fen> finds the solution or explanation to the outstanding mystery or <fen>Problem</fen>.
The <fen>Problem</fen> is the predicament or mystery that is resolved.
The <fen>Cause</fen> is the non-Agentive event or state of affairs that brings about the resolution of the <fen>Problem</fen>.
This role indicates the <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Problem</fen> is resolved.
This role indicates the location at which the <fen>Problem</fen> is resolved.
A concrete thing or abstract phenomenon or fact that is assessed in terms of how well recognizable it is to a <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The (typically non-specific and backgrounded) sentient being for whom the <fen>Entity</fen> possesses a specified level of recognizability.
The deviation of the actual level of recognizability of the <fen>Entity</fen> from the level specified by the target.
The person or object that is being evaluated for its desirability.
The time when the Evaluee is judged to be desirable.
The geographic area where an <fen>Evaluee</fen> is considered desirable.
The <fen>Behavior</fen> which is trendy.
The <fen>Evaluee</fen> is judged to conform to some degree with popular fashion with respect to his or her behavior.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Behavior</fen> is trendy or fashionable.
The location where the <fen>Behavior</fen> is trendy..

This is the person (or people) to whom a mental property is attributed. The role may be expressed as External Argument of a predicative use of the adjective, as a PP Complement, or as the head noun modified by an attributive use of the adjective:

The <fen>Behavior</fen> refers to any action, utterance, belief, or artifact thereof on the basis of which a mental property is attributed to the <fen>Protagonist</fen>. The meaning of the English word <ment>behavior</ment> should not be taken to constrain the identity of this frame element too much---conceptually, this frame element includes things that would not normally be described using the word <ment>behavior</ment>.  Note the following examples:

Some of the words in this frame have a slightly different use in that they evaluate someone only with respect to their mental performance in some particular domain or capacity.  We call this domain or capacity <t>Practice</t>. E.g., She is <t>astute</t> <fex name='Practice'>at math</fex>. Note that this does not mean she is considered to be astute in general for doing math. Rather, she is astute with respect to math, but may be dumb with respect to other things. These uses probably belong in a different frame with words such as <ment>skilled</ment>, but for the time being they are marked with the role Practice. General Grammatical Observations:  The adjectives in this frame may exhibit Extraposition of a <ment>to</ment>-marked infinitive VP, with an optional Protagonist expressed in an <ment>of</ment>-PP: It was <t>brilliant</t> (of you) <fex name='Prac'>to invite the clowns to the party</fex>.
listRoleExamples: Certain academic works are obscure <fex>only in North America</fex>.
If <fex>we</fex> have not been able to resolve a problem to your satisfaction, please email us.
Likewise, once the students worked through <fex>the problem</fex> and obtained their results, their next assignment would be to publish these to the web.
First, <fex>the Tripartite Agreement of 1979</fex> actually solved the only significant friction between the two countries.
A group of international scientists solved the fundamental particle hierarchy question <fex>at an underground accelerator</fex>.
He gave <fex>an address</fex> quite familiar to the chauffeur.
The information used to illustrate the concept is familiar <fex>to the reader</fex>.
He gave an address <fex>quite</fex> familiar to the chauffeur.
Electronica is all the rage <fex>in Europe</fex>.
<fex>You</fex> were smart to save all your receipts.
